creditline: Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund
inscribed:
Inscribed, recto lower left margin: Fragonard 1778 Sculp. Invenit; 


Inscribed, recto lower center margin: L’ARMOIRE

makers.displaydate: 1732–1806; born Grasse, France; died Paris, France
makers.displaymaker: Jean-Honoré Fragonard, 1732–1806; born Grasse, France; died Paris, France

texts.textentryhtml: [Paul McCarron, NYC]; purchased by James Bergquist, Brookline, MA,  in 1980s; sold to private collectors, Philadelphia, PA, who placed it on consignment to James Bergquist in 2020; purchased by Princeton University Art Museum, 2022.

When Fragonard published and advertised this print in November 1778, it was an instant bestseller, reflecting the current vogue among the French middle class for both moralizing and erotically suggestive tableaux, as mainly represented in affordable reproductive prints after popular paintings. Of the artist’s own invention, this domestic scene is based on a simple and crowd-pleasing plotline: angry parents burst into the bedroom of their daughter and discover her weeping in the corner after her lover has been found hiding in the large cupboard. Rumpled bedclothes reveal recent activity, while the yapping dog, puzzled children, and nosy neighbors provide a motley chorus—inviting us to join in as voyeurs.

displaymaker: Jean-Honoré Fragonard, 1732–1806; born Grasse, France; died Paris, France
caption: Jean-Honoré Fragonard (1732–1806; born Grasse, France; died Paris, France), L'armoire (The Cupboard), 1778. Etching; 40.6 × 53.5 cm (plate), 42.8 × 55.9 cm (sheet). Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund (2022-85)
